required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Buprenorphine Sublingual Spray for the Treatment of Moderate to Severe Pain
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 3, Randomized, Double Blind, Multiple Dose, Parallel Group, Placebo Controlled Study of Buprenorphine Sublingual Spray (0.5 mg TID, 0.25 mg TID, and 0.125 mg TID) for the Treatment of Moderate to Severe Pain

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this trial is to evaluate analgesic efficacy of Buprenorphine Sublingual (under the tongue) Spray compared with placebo in participants with postoperative pain after bunionectomy.

primary_outcome.measure: Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) Summed Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) Over 0 to 48 Hours After Time 0 (NRS SPID-48)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 0 to 48 hours after Time 0
primary_outcome.description: Pain intensity was assessed by the participant using an 11-point NRS from 0=no pain to 10=worst possible pain. Pain intensity scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (administration of first dose of study drug). Pain intensity difference is calculated by subtracting the pain intensity at each time point from the pain intensity at Time 0. The SPID scores are the sum of the differences at each time point multiplied by the duration in hours since the previous time point. Positive numbers indicate a reduction in pain [maximum(max)=10 at each time point], and negative numbers indicate an increase in pain [minimum(min)=-10 at each time point]. The overall min and max are -10 and 10 times the number of hours specified; SPID-48 range is -480 to 480. The NRS SPID-48 was analyzed using an analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) model, which included treatment and site as main effects and Baseline pain intensity as the covariate.

secondary_outcome.measure: NRS Mean Pain Intensity Difference (PID) at 4, 8, 24 and 48 Hours After Time 0
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 4, 8, 24 and 48 hours after Time 0
secondary_outcome.description: Pain intensity was assessed by the participant using an 11-point NRS from 0=no pain to 10=worst possible pain. Pain intensity scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug administration) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (time of administration of the first dose of study drug). NRS PID is defined as the difference in pain at each scheduled timepoint relative to Baseline (PID=pain intensity at baseline - pain intensity at time point). A higher value of NRS PID score indicates a higher decrease in pain from Baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: NRS Mean Pain Intensity Score at 4, 8, 24 and 48 Hours After Time 0
secondary_outcome.description: Pain intensity was assessed by the participant using an 11-point NRS from 0=no pain to 10=worst possible pain. Pain intensity scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug administration) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (time of administration of the first dose of study drug). A lower value indicates improvement in pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: NRS SPID Over 4 Hours (SPID-4), 8 Hours (SPID-8) and 24 Hours (SPID-24) After Time 0
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 0 to 4, 0 to 8 and 0 to 24 hours after Time 0
secondary_outcome.description: Pain intensity was assessed by the participant using an 11-point NRS from 0=no pain to 10=worst possible pain. Pain intensity scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (administration of first dose of study drug). Pain intensity difference is calculated by subtracting the pain intensity at each time point from the pain intensity at Time 0. The SPID scores are the sum of the differences at each time point multiplied by the duration in hours since the previous time point. Positive numbers indicate a reduction in pain [max=10 at each time point] and negative numbers indicate an increase in pain [min=-10 at each time point]. The overall min and max are -10 and 10 times the number of hours specified: SPID-4=(-40 to 40), SPID-8=(-80 to 80) and SPID-24=(-240 to 240). The NRS SPID-4, 8 and 24 were analyzed using an ANCOVA model which included treatment and site as main effects and Baseline pain intensity as the covariate.

secondary_outcome.measure: Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) Over 4, 8, 24 and 48 Hours After Time 0
secondary_outcome.description: TOTPAR was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). TOTPAR scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (first dose of study drug). The TOTPAR scores are the sum of the pain relief at each time point multiplied by the duration in hours since the previous time point. Larger positive numbers indicate more pain relief (maximum=4 at each time point) and smaller positive numbers indicate less pain relief (minimum=0 at each time point). The overall minimum is 0 for each variable and the overall maximum is 4 times the number of hours specified for the variable: TOTPAR-4=(0 to 16), TOTPAR-8=(0 to 32), TOTPAR-24=(0 to 96) and TOTPAR-48=(0 to 192). TOTPAR-4, TOTPAR-8, TOTPAR-24 and TOTPAR-48 were analyzed using an ANCOVA model with factors for treatment, site and baseline pain intensity.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of confirmed meaningful pain relief (up to 64 minutes)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to onset of analgesia was measured as time to first perceptible pain relief confirmed by meaningful pain relief using the 2-stopwatch method. The study staff started 2 stopwatches as soon as the first dose of study drug was administered. Each participant was instructed to stop the first stopwatch when he or she experienced any perceptible pain relief and the second stopwatch when he or she experienced pain relief that was meaningful to them. If the second stopwatch was not stopped, time was censored at the time of the second dose of study drug or the use of rescue medication, whichever came first. If both stopwatches were not stopped time was censored at the time of the second dose of study drug or the use of rescue medication whichever came first. Time to onset of analgesia was defined as the time when the first stopwatch was stopped given that the second stopwatch is stopped.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Scores in Each Pain Relief Category at 4, 8, 24 and 48 Hours After Time 0
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 4, 8, 24 and 48 hours after Time 0 (first dose of study drug)
secondary_outcome.description: Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). The percentage of participants with scores in each pain relief category are reported. Missing values were imputed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Peak Scores in Each Pain Relief Category
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) up to 48 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Peak pain relief is the highest value of pain relief experienced during the study. Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). The percentage of participants with peak scores in each pain relief category are reported.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of peak pain relief (up to 1437 minutes)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to peak pain relief is the time to the highest value of pain relief experienced during the study. Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). If no pain relief was observed, then the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Perceptible Pain Relief
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of first perceptible pain relief (up to 83 minutes)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to first perceptible pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the first stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of meaningful pain relief (up to 227 minutes)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to meaningful pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the second stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Using Rescue Medication for Pain
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) up to 48 hours
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of participants who needed to take an alternate medication for pain relief during the treatment period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Use of Rescue Medication for Pain
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 to time of first use of rescue medication (up to 280 minutes)
secondary_outcome.description: Time to first use of rescue medication is the time from Time 0 (time of administration of the first dose of study drug) to the first use of rescue medication. If rescue medication was not taken the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Total Use of Rescue Medication Over 0 to 24 Hours and 0 to 48 Hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Over 24 and 48 hours after Time 0 (first dose of study drug)
secondary_outcome.description: Total use of rescue medication is defined as the number of times a participant took rescue medication.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant's Global Evaluation of Study Drug
secondary_outcome.time_frame: End of treatment (Day 3) or early termination
secondary_outcome.description: Global evaluation of study drug was completed at the end of treatment (Day 3) or before early termination if a participant discontinued early. Participants were asked to provide an overall rating of their study medication in controlling pain on a 5-point NRS, where 0=poor, 1=fair, 2=good, 3=very good, and 4=excellent. The percentage of participants with scores in each pain relief category are reported.

arm_group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.5 mg sublingual (under the tongue) spray three times daily (TID) for two days.
Participants received buprenorphine 0.25 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.
Participants received buprenorphine 0.125 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.
Participants received placebo-matching buprenorphine sublingual spray TID for two days.

intervention.description: Buprenorphine sublingual spray delivered via single 100 μL spray
Placebo-matching buprenorphine sublingual spray delivered via single 100 μL spray

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Meets protocol-specified criteria for qualification and contraception
- Willing and able to remain confined in the study unit for the entire duration of each treatment period and comply with restrictions related food, drink and medications
- Voluntarily consents to participate and provides written informed consent prior to any protocol-specific procedures
Exclusion Criteria:
- History or current use of over-the-counter medications, dietary supplements, or drugs (including nicotine and alcohol) outside protocol-specified parameters
- Signs, symptoms or history of any condition that, per protocol or in the opinion of the investigator, might compromise:
1. the safety or well-being of the participant or study staff;
2. the safety or well-being of the participant's offspring (such as through pregnancy or breast-feeding);
3. the analysis of results

group.description: Participants received placebo-matching buprenorphine sublingual (under the tongue) spray TID for two days.

group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.5 mg sublingual spray three times daily (TID) for two days.

baseline.population: Safety Population included all participants who were treated with the study drug.

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Numeric Rating Scale (NRS) Summed Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) Over 0 to 48 Hours After Time 0 (NRS SPID-48)
outcome.description: Pain intensity was assessed by the participant using an 11-point NRS from 0=no pain to 10=worst possible pain. Pain intensity scores were collected at Baseline (prior to study drug) and at multiple time points up to 48 hours after Time 0 (administration of first dose of study drug). Pain intensity difference is calculated by subtracting the pain intensity at each time point from the pain intensity at Time 0. The SPID scores are the sum of the differences at each time point multiplied by the duration in hours since the previous time point. Positive numbers indicate a reduction in pain [maximum(max)=10 at each time point], and negative numbers indicate an increase in pain [minimum(min)=-10 at each time point]. The overall min and max are -10 and 10 times the number of hours specified; SPID-48 range is -480 to 480. The NRS SPID-48 was analyzed using an analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) model, which included treatment and site as main effects and Baseline pain intensity as the covariate.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline and 0 to 48 hours after Time 0
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the Intent-to-Treat (ITT) Population who did not have missing SPID-48 values. Missing SPID-48 data were not imputed.

analysis.method_desc: The analysis included treatment and site as main effects and Baseline pain intensity as the covariate.

outcome.title: Time to Onset of Analgesia
outcome.description: Time to onset of analgesia was measured as time to first perceptible pain relief confirmed by meaningful pain relief using the 2-stopwatch method. The study staff started 2 stopwatches as soon as the first dose of study drug was administered. Each participant was instructed to stop the first stopwatch when he or she experienced any perceptible pain relief and the second stopwatch when he or she experienced pain relief that was meaningful to them. If the second stopwatch was not stopped, time was censored at the time of the second dose of study drug or the use of rescue medication, whichever came first. If both stopwatches were not stopped time was censored at the time of the second dose of study drug or the use of rescue medication whichever came first. Time to onset of analgesia was defined as the time when the first stopwatch was stopped given that the second stopwatch is stopped.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of confirmed meaningful pain relief (up to 64 minutes)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received placebo-matching buprenorphine sublingual (under the tongue) spray TID for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.5 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.5 mg sublingual spray three times daily (TID) for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.25 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.25 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.125 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.125 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Peak Scores in Each Pain Relief Category
measure.description: Peak pain relief is the highest value of pain relief experienced during the study. Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). The percentage of participants with peak scores in each pain relief category are reported.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population

class.title: A lot of relief + Complete relief

outcome.title: Time to Peak Pain Relief
outcome.description: Time to peak pain relief is the time to the highest value of pain relief experienced during the study. Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). If no pain relief was observed, then the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of peak pain relief (up to 1437 minutes)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Participants received placebo-matching buprenorphine sublingual (under the tongue) spray TID for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.5 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.5 mg sublingual spray three times daily (TID) for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.25 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.25 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.

group.title: Buprenorphine 0.125 mg TID
group.description: Participants received buprenorphine 0.125 mg sublingual spray TID for two days.

measure.title: Time to Peak Pain Relief
measure.description: Time to peak pain relief is the time to the highest value of pain relief experienced during the study. Pain relief was assessed by the participant using a 5-point NRS (0=no relief, 1=a little, 2=some, 3=a lot, 4=complete relief). If no pain relief was observed, then the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population

outcome.title: Time to First Perceptible Pain Relief
outcome.description: Time to first perceptible pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the first stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of first perceptible pain relief (up to 83 minutes)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measure.title: Time to First Perceptible Pain Relief
measure.description: Time to first perceptible pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the first stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

outcome.title: Time to Meaningful Pain Relief
outcome.description: Time to meaningful pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the second stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) to time of meaningful pain relief (up to 227 minutes)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measure.title: Time to Meaningful Pain Relief
measure.description: Time to meaningful pain relief was evaluated using the 2 stopwatch method and is defined as the time when the participant stops the second stopwatch. If it was not stopped time was censored at the time that the second stopwatch was stopped or the time of the second dose or the time that rescue medication was used whichever came first.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measurement_list.measurement: Not estimable because less than 50% of participants achieved meaningful pain relief

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants Using Rescue Medication for Pain
outcome.description: The percentage of participants who needed to take an alternate medication for pain relief during the treatment period.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 (first dose of study drug) up to 48 hours
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants Using Rescue Medication for Pain
measure.description: The percentage of participants who needed to take an alternate medication for pain relief during the treatment period.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

outcome.title: Time to First Use of Rescue Medication for Pain
outcome.description: Time to first use of rescue medication is the time from Time 0 (time of administration of the first dose of study drug) to the first use of rescue medication. If rescue medication was not taken the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.
outcome.time_frame: From Time 0 to time of first use of rescue medication (up to 280 minutes)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measure.title: Time to First Use of Rescue Medication for Pain
measure.description: Time to first use of rescue medication is the time from Time 0 (time of administration of the first dose of study drug) to the first use of rescue medication. If rescue medication was not taken the time was censored at the time of the last pain assessment.
measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

measurement_list.measurement: Not estimable because too few participants used rescue medication

outcome.title: Total Use of Rescue Medication Over 0 to 24 Hours and 0 to 48 Hours
outcome.description: Total use of rescue medication is defined as the number of times a participant took rescue medication.
outcome.time_frame: Over 24 and 48 hours after Time 0 (first dose of study drug)
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population who used rescue medication during the specified time intervals.

measure.title: Total Use of Rescue Medication Over 0 to 24 Hours and 0 to 48 Hours

measure.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population who used rescue medication during the specified time intervals.

outcome.title: Participant's Global Evaluation of Study Drug
outcome.description: Global evaluation of study drug was completed at the end of treatment (Day 3) or before early termination if a participant discontinued early. Participants were asked to provide an overall rating of their study medication in controlling pain on a 5-point NRS, where 0=poor, 1=fair, 2=good, 3=very good, and 4=excellent. The percentage of participants with scores in each pain relief category are reported.
outcome.time_frame: End of treatment (Day 3) or early termination
outcome.population: All randomized participants from the ITT Population.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
